journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Fault-tolerant driving control of a steer-by-wire system for six-wheel-driving–six-wheel-steering vehicles

article-meta.aff: 1Graduate School of Convergence Science and Technology, Seoul National University, Seoul, Republic of Korea
2Program in Automotive Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul, Republic of Korea
3School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul, Republic of Korea
4Agency for Defense Development, Daejeon, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: Kyongsu Yi, School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Seoul National University, San 56-1 Gwanak-gu, Shillim-dong 56-1, Seoul, Republic of Korea. Email: kyi@snu.ac.kr

abstract.p: This paper describes a fault-tolerant driving control strategy for steer-by-wire system failures in six-wheel-driving–six-wheel-steering vehicles. The fault-tolerant driving control algorithm was designed to obtain vehicle manoeuvrability as close as possible to that of non-faulty vehicles by redistributing the tractive forces of the non-faulty wheels. Since a faulty steer-by-wire system induces a high lateral tyre force, which is the resistance to the yaw motion of the vehicle, a high-wheel slip control strategy is used to minimize the resistive lateral tyre force of the faulty steer-by-wire system. The fault-tolerant driving performance of a faulty six-wheel-driving–six-wheel-steering vehicle was investigated via computer simulations. To investigate the effectiveness of the proposed fault-tolerant driving control algorithm, the fault recovery rate was defined and calculated in terms of the vehicle manoeuvrability. Simulation studies show that the proposed fault-tolerant driving control algorithm can significantly improve the vehicle manoeuvrability, compared with the optimal traction redistribution method.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: An independent six-wheel-driving (6WD)–six-wheel-steering (6WS) mechanism is adopted in a special-purpose vehicle to enhance its manoeuvring performance and its off-road driving capability. A six-wheeled vehicle is believed to have better manoeuvrability than a four-wheeled vehicle does in terms of its capability of crossing obstacles and off-road manoeuvring. To achieve the best manoeuvrability during cornering for a 6WD–6WS vehicle, the steering angle and traction torque of each wheel need to be controlled to improve the handling (manoeuvring) performance of the vehicle.1–5

Drive-by-wire systems such as steer-by-wire systems, brake-by-wire systems and in-wheel motors should be developed to maximize the advantages of 6WD and 6WD systems.6 A steer-by-wire system of each wheel component can provide not only an Ackerman steering geometry but also parallel and negative rear-wheel steering geometries, etc.7 Using individual brake systems and in-wheel motors, a heavy vehicle can achieve optimal traction distribution, thereby allowing it to manoeuvre according to the desired longitudinal and yaw motions with agility even in off-road conditions.8 However, since there is no direct mechanical connection between the driver and actuators of drive-by-wire systems, electronic robustness plays a major role in their safety. Double, triple or even quadruple redundant sensors, actuators, communication networks and engine control units are needed to achieve a high level of reliability,9,10 but this increases the overall cost and weight of the vehicle. In particular, a failed steer-by-wire actuator or sensor can reduce the manoeuvring performance, because this can generate a negative lateral tyre force that can disturb the yaw motion of the vehicle.

In this paper, a fault-tolerant driving control for the steer-by-wire system of a 6WD–6WS vehicle is described. The goal of this research is to recover the vehicle manoeuvrability in the case of a faulty steer-by-wire system by redistributing the traction control commands. One of the recent developments in the fault-tolerant driving control of a by-wire system is due to the research by Hac.11 Hac designed a methodology for mitigating the consequences of potential brake actuator failure in vehicles with brake-by-wire and possibly steer-by-wire systems. However, this study did not cover the failure of the steer-by-wire system. Zheng and co-workers10,12,13 proposed a fault-tolerant steer-by-wire system which supports single-point failures without degrading the control performance of a system with a dual-motor and dual-microcontroller architecture, but two motors and two controllers must be employed to use this architecture.

In previous studies, driving controllers for independent four-wheeled or six-wheeled vehicles were designed on the basis of optimal distribution control and take into consideration the friction circle related to the vertical tyre force and friction coefficient acting on the road and tyre to enhance their manoeuvrability and stability.14–16 However, this strategy cannot cover all steering-system failure circumstances, because the tyre forces of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire system can disturb the manoeuvring of the vehicle. To reduce the resistance generated by the lateral tyre force in the case of a steer-by-wire system failure, a high-slip-based fault-tolerant driving controller is designed in this research.

The development of a fault-tolerant driving controller for dealing with steer-by-wire system failures in a 6WD–6WS vehicle and the investigation of its performance are presented in this paper. The 6WD–6WS vehicle system and TruckSim vehicle dynamic model are discussed in the second section. The fault-tolerant driving controller consists of an upper-level controller and lower-level controller, which are discussed in the third section. The upper-level controller determines the longitudinal and lateral dynamic motions intended by the driver using vehicle dynamic equations. The lower-level controller is based on the optimal traction distribution method. The resistance from the lateral tyre force of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component cannot be reduced sufficiently by the optimal traction redistribution method, where the term ‘redistribution’ indicates that the control commands to certain wheels can be reduced or blocked using the weighting factors of those wheels having small or zero values in this paper. To reduce the resistance from the lateral tyre force of a wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component, the proposed fault-tolerant driving control algorithm is designed to generate a high slip ratio of the wheel. To investigate the effectiveness of the proposed fault-tolerant algorithm, in comparison with that of the existing optimal traction redistribution method, driving simulations were performed and the fault recovery rate was defined in terms of the manoeuvrability. These simulation results are described and analysed in the fourth section. Finally, the conclusion is presented in the last section.

sec.title: 6WD–6WS vehicle layout
sec.p: A full six-wheeled vehicle including drive-by-wire components is modelled as the object of this research. A 6WD–6WS vehicle consists of six independent driving components which include the respective in-wheel motors including gear reducers, brake actuators and steer-by-wire components (steering actuators), as shown in Figure 1. A specific description of the 6WD–6WS vehicle model is given in Table 1.

caption.p: 6WD–6WS vehicle layout.
Specifications of the 6WD–6WS vehicle model.

tr.td: Distance from the centre of gravity to the front axle
Distance from the centre of gravity to the middle axle
Distance from the centre of gravity to the rear axle

sec.p: Most steer-by-wire systems are designed using the conventional Ackerman steering geometry. In some test vehicles, all the stock components of the conventional steering system are used except for the intermediate steering shaft, which is replaced by a brushless d.c. motor to provide steering actuation.17,18 A 6WD–6WS vehicle is equipped with independent steer-by-wire systems to deal with various steering strategies. An independent steer-by-wire system of one wheel component consists of a steering motor, a rack-pinion gear and a gear position sensor, as shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: Steer-by-wire system of each wheel.

sec.p: A 6WD–6WS vehicle equipped with six in-wheel motors is able to operate differential tractive and braking modes to enhance the vehicle manoeuvrability, because the motors can be controlled independently. To satisfy the required performance specifications, a motor capacity of 60 kW which is accompanied by a gear reducer is selected. Figure 3 shows the structure of the in-wheel motors and the torque–angular velocity diagram. The maximum torque depends on the capacity of the in-wheel motor and is determined by the angular velocity of the operating wheel.

caption.p: Wheel angular speed–torque curve of an in-wheel motor.

sec.title: TruckSim vehicle model
sec.p: In this research, the driving simulation program TruckSim is used for vehicle dynamic modelling. A 6WD–6WS vehicle dynamic model consists of 24-degree-of-freedom dynamic models such as the translational and rotational dynamic models of the sprung mass, six suspension models, six wheel dynamic models and six steering dynamic models. The wheel dynamics contain the in-wheel motor, brake system and tyre models. The full-vehicle dynamic model of TruckSim makes it possible to analyse the driving behaviour of a 6WD–6WS vehicle on the road, which can be driven by both an open-loop-steering–throttle–braking profile and closed-loop path tracking with a driver model included. This modelling consists of nine subcomponents: sprung mass, aerodynamics, animator shape, tyre model, steering-wheel torque, suspension kinematics, spring and damper, brakes and steering kinematics.

The heavy truck tyre 365/80R 20 XZL is on the 6WD–6WS vehicle model. Since there are no data for the characteristics of this tyre, the tyre characteristics of a 315/80R 22.5 tyre19 and a 14.00R 20 tyre,20 which are similar in size, were used as data for tyre modelling in TruckSim. Figure 4(a) and (b) shows the longitudinal tyre force map and the lateral tyre force map respectively, and Figure 5 shows the self-aligning moment map.

caption.p: (a) Longitudinal tyre force map and (b) lateral tyre force map for several fixed values of the vertical tyre force.
Tyre slip angle: aligning moment map.

sec.title: Fault-tolerant driving control algorithm
sec.p: The goal of the fault-tolerant driving control considered in this research is to determine the traction control commands appropriate for the failure of a steer-by-wire component, which can be detected by steer-by-wire fault detection algorithms.21,22Figure 6 represents the scheme of the fault-tolerant driving control of a 6WD–6WS vehicle. Note that the vehicle speed Vx and the vertical load μFzi can be estimated using the Kobayashi et al.23 method and the Kim et al.24 method respectively. The vertical load μFzi can be simply estimated using longitudinal and lateral acceleration sensors.25 It is assumed that the fault information for each wheel component is obtained from each motor controller precisely. Table 2 shows the list of components and faults of independent steer-by-wire systems.

caption.p: Fault-tolerant driving control scheme.
List of components and faults of steer-by-wire systems.

tr.td: Power shut off, overheat, out of connection
Power shut off, out of connection
Wheel locked, wheel taken out, puncture

sec.p: Most of the integrated driving controllers for 4WD or 6WD–6WS vehicles developed in previous studies consist of upper-level control and lower-level control.14–16,24 Similarly, the proposed fault-tolerant controller consists of an upper-level controller and lower-level controller. The upper-level controller determines the longitudinal and lateral dynamic motions intended by the driver using the vehicle dynamic equations discussed in the section on the upper-level controller design. The objectives of the lower-level control are to minimize the traction control input and to determine the distributed tyre forces by using the optimal tyre force distribution method, which is discussed in the section on the optimal tyre force distribution. The proposed fault-tolerant driving control strategy is based on the high-slip-based optimal tyre force distribution, which is discussed in the section on high-slip-based tyre force distibution control. By using the high-slip-based fault-tolerant driving control strategy, a wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component spins with a high slip ratio to reduce the lateral tyre force. Because the lateral tyre force of the wheel with a failure is reduced, the vehicle can take advantage of the high-slip control strategy to maximize the dynamic manoeuvrability.

sec.title: Upper-level controller design
sec.p: The upper-level controller uses the driver’s steering-wheel angle and desired velocity as the inputs and determines the steering angle of each wheel component, the required yaw moment and the net longitudinal force as the outputs. Figure 7 shows the scheme of the upper-level controller.

caption.p: Upper-level controller scheme.
PID: proportional–integral–derivative.

sec.p: The desired net longitudinal force for tracking the desired speed is computed by proportional–integral–derivative (PID) control as

In many studies of four-wheel vehicles, the desired lateral yaw-rate model is applied to define a linearized bicycle model. Also, a bicycle model of the 6WD–6WS vehicle can be simply designed as shown in Figure 8. In this bicycle model, the longitudinal forces, vertical motion, roll motion and pitch motion are neglected.

caption.p: Bicycle model of the 6WD–6WS vehicle.

sec.p: The desired yaw rate is defined in terms of a bicycle model which has three wheels. It is defined as the first-order differential equation
where

In linear models, the lateral forces are regarded as linear functions of the slip angle, assuming that the slip angle is very small. However, the assumption that the lateral forces are linear to the tyre slip angle is valid only when the tyre slip angle is less than 3°. To track the proposed single-target yaw rate, a yaw-rate controller is designed on the basis of sliding-mode control.
The sliding surface is defined as the yaw-rate error, which is the difference between the actual yaw rate and the reference yaw rate, according to

The control objective is to keep the scalar s at zero and this can be achieved by choosing the control law satisfying the sliding-condition states. To prevent chattering near the surface, the saturation function with region Φ is substituted for sgn(s) to give
By using the two-degree-of-freedom bicycle model including the additional desired yaw moment term ΔMz_des, the differential equation can be achieved by setting
Finally, the required yaw moment can be written as

sec.title: Optimal tyre force distribution
sec.p: The lower-level controller is designed to distribute the additional tractive–braking forces for the purpose of generating the net longitudinal force and required yaw moment, based on the optimal tyre force distribution method. Figure 9 represents a block diagram of the lower-level controller, which redistributes the longitudinal tyre force to each wheel, considering the fault information for each steer-by-wire component. In the case of failure of an actuator, the weighting factor of the wheel with the faulty actuator can be set to zero, in order to achieve free-wheeling conditions.

caption.p: Lower-level controller scheme with optimal tyre force redistribution.

sec.p: The additional longitudinal tyre force distribution is determined by the optimal control law. The performance index can be defined as a combination of the control inputs, friction circles and weighting factors. The proposed performance index is selected as15,16,24,25

Because the variances of the weighting factors (cx1,cx2,…,cx6) are ineffective, all of them are set to 1 if there is no fault. The control inputs should be satisfied with constraints related to the net longitudinal force and required yaw moment. These constraints are given by
where tfmr = tf = tm = tr.

By considering equations (8) and (9), it can be seen that the additional longitudinal tyre forces of wheels 5 and 6 are dependent variables that can be expressed as functions of the other independent variables according to
By substituting the above equations for the two variables in equation (7), the performance index with four independent variables can be represented as
The necessary conditions for minimizing the performance index can be written as
Through equations (13) to (16), the optimal state is defined using independent variables and the state equation is reformulated as
where
With the additional torque of each wheel computed by equation (17), the longitudinal tyre force distributed to each wheel can be determined as

In the case of the failure of a steer-by-wire system, in order to rotate the wheel freely with a faulty steer-by-wire component, the torque command to this wheel must be zero, while those to the others are optimally determined. For example, when a fault occurs in a component of the steer-by-wire system of wheel 1, the weighting factor cx1 is selected to be zero. Also, the distributed longitudinal tyre force is zero, while those of the other five wheels are determined optimally. This strategy is given by
where n is the number of wheels with faulty steer-by-wire components. Finally, the wheel torque control input is obtained as

sec.title: High-slip-based tyre force distribution control
sec.p: Even though the longitudinal tyre force of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component can be set to zero by the optimal tyre force redistribution method based on previous studies, the lateral tyre force of the wheel cannot be reduced. The resistance resulting from the lateral tyre force of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component cannot be reduced sufficiently by the optimal tyre force redistribution strategy. To solve this problem, the proposed fault-tolerant driving control algorithm assigns a high slip ratio of the wheel, using the tyre force characteristics. This high slip ratio can be simply induced using PID control. Considering the transition of the longitudinal tyre force of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component owing to its high slip, the longitudinal tyre forces are optimally distributed to the other (non-faulty) wheels. Figure 10 shows the lower-level controller which tolerates the steer-by-wire fault by using a high slip ratio.

caption.p: Lower-level controller: fault-tolerant driving control using a high slip ratio.
PID: proportional–integral–derivative.

sec.p: According to Pacejka’s combined tyre model, the lateral tyre force can be reduced because of the presence of the longitudinal tyre slip. The combined tyre force is given by26
where

and where Fx0(λ, Fz) and Fy0(α, Fz) represent the pure longitudinal tyre characteristics and the pure lateral tyre characteristics respectively. Figure 11 is a combined tyre map which shows examples of the lateral tyre force and longitudinal tyre force as functions of the slip ratio, for several fixed values of the slip angle.

caption.p: Combined map of the tyre forces as functions of the slip ratio, for several fixed values of the slip angle.

sec.p: The slip ratio of each wheel can be defined as a function of the wheel speed and the vehicle speed according to
where
The wheel speed of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component required to induce a high slip ratio is calculated as

To reduce the lateral tyre force, the high slip ratioλmax_f is set to 0.8 according to the combined tyre map. From equation (21), if λmax_f in equation (23) is set to 0.8, the lateral tyre force is reduced by 57% compared with the case where the slip ratio is set to less than 0.1, when the slip angle is 20° (When the slip angle is 10°, the lateral tyre force is reduced by 75%.) Thus, the disturbance term is reduced to
where
To track the wheel speed, the input torque of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component is designed using PID control according to

To consider the transition of the longitudinal tyre force of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component due to high slip, the longitudinal tyre force is estimated. The longitudinal tyre force can be simply estimated using the input torque of the wheel and the angular acceleration of the wheel according to

The angular acceleration of the wheel can be estimated using the measured angular velocity of the wheel. The state equation for the estimation of the angular acceleration of the wheel is obtained from the Taylor formula for the angular velocity of the wheel as27

where ΔT is the measuring update period and di(k) represents the higher-order terms. The longitudinal tyre force of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component depends on the high-slip control, so that the optimal tyre force distribution process of the wheels with non-faulty steer-by-wire components must be redesigned. The constraints given in equations (8) and (9) are rewritten as
where
If the steer-by-wire component of wheel 1 or wheel 3 is faulty, equation (7) is rewritten as
In the same way, if the steer-by-wire component of wheel 2 or wheel 4 is faulty, equation (8) is rewritten as
If the steer-by-wire component of wheel 5 or wheel 6 is faulty, the dependent variable is replaced with another variable according to

For instance, in the case where the steer-by-wire component of wheel 1 is faulty, the necessary condition given by equation (13) is neglected, those in equations (14) to (16) are recalculated and, finally, the additional longitudinal tyre force of wheels 2 to 4 can be calculated as
where

Finally, the longitudinal tyre forces of the wheels with non-faulty steer-by-wire components are assigned to compensate for the increase in the longitudinal tyre force of the wheel with the faulty steer-by-wire component, according to

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p: To investigate the proposed fault-tolerant driving algorithm, computer simulations were conducted in which the steer-by-wire system of the front left-wheel component fails. The fault-tolerant driving controller was implemented using MATLAB Simulink, while the driver model, vehicle model and road conditions provided by Trucksim were used. It is assumed that failure of the steer-by-wire system is detected within 0.1 s. The results obtained with the proposed high-slip-based fault-tolerant driving controller are compared with those from the optimal redistribution method.

sec.title: Open-loop steering simulation
sec.p: Open-loop steering simulation studies were conducted with the prescribed steering profile, while the vehicle speed tracks the desired speed. In these simulation studies, the steering angle of each wheel is determined according to the Ackerman steering geometry, and the steering system of wheel 1 begins to fail from 3 s, as shown in Figure 12.

caption.p: Steering angle of each wheel during the fish-hook test.

sec.p: Figure 13 shows the result of the fish-hook and steady state turning test when the desired speed is set to 30 km/h. When the failure begins, the vehicle speed and yaw rate are reduced with the optimal tyre force redistribution, as shown in Figure 13(a) and (b) respectively, while the vehicle speed and the yaw rate are improved by the proposed fault-tolerant driving controller using high slip.

caption.p: (a) Vehicle speed and (b) yaw rate during the 30 km/h fish-hook and steady state turning test.

sec.p: Figure 14 shows the maximum stable yaw-rate curve of the 6WD–6WS vehicle. This figure was drawn by recording the maximum stable yaw rate with respect to a constant vehicle speed, where the term ‘stable’ signifies that the side-slip angle is smaller than 0.1 rad. Since the lateral speed Vy of the vehicle is constant in the case of steady state turning, the maximum stable yaw rate is inversely proportional to the longitudinal speed Vx of the vehicle. However, at speeds less than 30 km/h, the maximum stable yaw rate is proportional to the longitudinal speed of the vehicle, owing to the mechanical limitation of the steering system. This figure shows that the manoeuvring performance of a vehicle with steer-by-wire system failure can be improved by the proposed fault-tolerant driving control algorithm, so that it resembles that of a non-faulty vehicle.

caption.p: Maximum stable yaw-rate curve.

sec.p: To investigate the effectiveness of the proposed fault-tolerant driving control algorithm, the fault recovery rate (FRR) is defined and calculated in terms of the maximum stable yaw rate as

In the case of open-loop steering steady state turning, the FRR in terms of the maximum stable yaw rate is 33.8%. This means that, in the worst case of independent steer-by-wire system failure, the high-slip-based fault-tolerant controller can improve limitation of the manoeuvring performance by 33.8%.

sec.title: Closed-loop steering simulation
sec.p: In this simulation, the vehicle with a driver model tracks a double-lane-change reference path, which measures 6 m in width. The steering angle is determined by the driver model, while the vehicle speed tracks the desired speed. Figure 15 describes the steering angle of each wheel during a double-lane-changing simulation. At 3 s, the front left-wheel steering system becomes faulty and is about 30° larger than the expected steering angle. Figure 16(a) shows the driver model’s steering command in the double-lane-changing manoeuvre. In the case of optimal tyre force redistribution with failure, the driver model needs more steering-wheel movement than in the case of the proposed fault-tolerant driving control, where the steering ratio of the vehicle model is 15:1. Figure 16(b) and (c) shows that the vehicle speed and yaw rate obtained with the proposed fault-tolerant driving controller are similar to those obtained with optimal redistribution, even though the driver model with optimal redistribution needs more steering-wheel movement.

caption.p: Front left-wheel (wheel 1) fault circumstance.
Results of closed-loop simulation: (a) driver model’s steering command; (b) vehicle speed; (c) yaw rate.

sec.p: Figure 17(a) and (b) shows the wheel torque outputs of wheel 1 and wheel 2 respectively. When a failure occurs at wheel 1, the optimal tyre force redistribution algorithm cuts off the torque output of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component, while the proposed fault-tolerant driving control algorithm sends a higher torque command to the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component to increase the wheel slip ratio. As a result, the lateral tyre force of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component is obviously decreased in the case of the proposed fault-tolerant driving control algorithm, as shown in Figure 18(a).

caption.p: Results of closed-loop simulation: (a) wheel torque of wheel 1; (b) wheel torque of wheel 2.
Results of closed-loop simulation: (a) lateral tyre force of wheel 1; (b) lateral tyre force of wheel 2.

sec.p: Figures 19 and 20 show the lateral error and the trajectory of this simulation respectively. These figures show that the proposed fault-tolerant driving controller enhances the path-tracking performance of the vehicle, in comparison with the optimal tyre force redistribution method. From these results of closed-loop simulation studies, it is found that the proposed high-slip-based fault-tolerant driving controller offers manoeuvrability and stability to the vehicle with a faulty steer-by-wire system, with less steering action of the driver, compared with the case of optimal tyre force redistribution.

caption.p: Results of closed-loop simulation: lateral error.
Trajectories of closed-loop simulation in the case of a double lane change.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A fault-tolerant driving control strategy for steer-by-wire system failures in 6WD–6WS vehicles was designed to improve the vehicle manoeuvrability. To reduce the resistance from the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component, the proposed fault-tolerant driving controller reduces the lateral tyre force of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component using high slip. From combined lateral–longitudinal tyre force characteristics, it can be shown that the lateral tyre force is reduced dramatically as the slip ratio increases. Considering the transition of the longitudinal tyre force of the wheel with a faulty steer-by-wire component, the longitudinal tyre forces are optimally distributed to the other wheels by using the optimal tyre force distribution method. To investigate the performance of the proposed fault-tolerant driving control algorithm, computer simulations were conducted and the FRR was calculated in terms of the manoeuvrability. The open-loop steering and closed-loop steering simulation studies using the TruckSim vehicle dynamic model show that the manoeuvring performance of the faulty vehicle with the proposed fault-tolerant driving control algorithm can be significantly improved, in comparison with the case of optimal tyre force redistribution in the case of the front left-wheel independent steer-by-wire system failure. The result of calculation of the FRR in terms of the maximum stable yaw rate shows that the high-slip-based fault-tolerant controller can improve limitation of the manoeuvring performance by 33.8%. From the results of the closed-loop simulation studies, it is found that the proposed high-slip-based fault-tolerant driving controller offers manoeuvrability and stability to a vehicle with a faulty steer-by-wire system, with less steering action of the driver, compared with the case of optimal tyre force redistribution.
An investigation on the driveability of the 6WD–6WS vehicle with the proposed fault-tolerant driving control algorithm in off-road conditions also need to be conducted via a test vehicle.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: cxi weighting factor of a longitudinal tyre force distribution at the ith wheel
Cf, Cm, Cr cornering stiffnesses for the front wheel, middle wheel and rear wheel respectively (N/rad)
Fxdes desired longitudinal net tyre force of the vehicle (N)
Fxi, Fyi, Fzi longitudinal tyre force, lateral tyre force and vertical tyre force respectively of the ith wheel (N)
Iz moment of inertia of the vehicle (kg m2)
Jω moment of inertia of the ith wheel (kg m2)
KP, KI, KD proportional control gain, integral control gain and derivative control gain respectively for proportional–integral–derivative control
lf, lm, lr distances from the centre of gravity to the front axle, middle axle and rear axle respectively (m)
m mass of the vehicle (kg)
r radius of the tyre (m)
tf, tm, tr treads of the front axle, middle axle and rear axle respectively of the vehicle (m)
Ti input wheel torque command of the ith wheel (N m)
Vdes desired longitudinal velocity of the vehicle (m/s)
x longitudinal global position of the vehicle (m)
y lateral global position of the vehicle (m)
αf, αm, αr tyre slip angles of the front wheel, middle wheel and rear wheel respectively of the bicycle model (rad)
β side-slip angle of the vehicle (rad)
γ yaw rate of the vehicle ( rad/s)
γdes desired yaw rate (rad/s)
δcomi steering input for the ith wheel (rad)
δdriver manual steering-wheel angle (by the driver) (rad)
δf, δm, δr steering inputs for the front wheel, middle wheel and rear wheel respectively of the bicycle model (rad)
δi steering angle of the ith wheel (rad)
ΔFxi additional coordinated longitudinal tyre force of the ith wheel (N)
ΔMz_des required net yaw moment (N m)
λi slip ratio of the ith wheel
λmax defined maximum wheel slip ratio
µi friction coefficient of the ith wheel
ωdes_i desired wheel speed for wheel speed control of the ith wheel (rad/s)
ωi wheel speed (angular velocity) of the ith wheel (rad/s)
